To their hot-blooded fans, the Dandy Warhols are dizzyingly inventive alternative-rock heroes. To the rest of the western world, they are the arrogant stars of rock documentaries and Vodafone adverts, and their achingly dull eighth album does little to alter that assessment. It starts with The World the People Together (Come On), a totally vague stadium anthem that has no heart or spine. Then things go downhill. Mission Control sounds like Marilyn Manson on an off day, Valerie Yum sounds like a post-lobotomy Super Furry Animals, and the lumpen funk of Welcome to the Third World is built around the lyric "You dance pretty good for an almost white girl", one of the band's many terrible attempts at hilarity. Mark Knopfler's weary guitar on Love Song is telling - revealing that a band who claim to offer more are actually content to peddle MOR.

Guitarist Wolfgang Muthspiel enjoys a fittingly world-class regular partnership with Wayne Shorter's drummer, Brian Blade. This joint audio/DVD package features their duo caught live in Muthspiel's native Austria. Though no clone, Muthspiel has been compared with Pat Metheny and John Scofield. But lately he's broadened his world music horizons, and this all-original set includes a dancing, chanting dedication to singer/percussionist Youssou N'Dour - unleashing the full Blade works on shakers, water-trickling sounds and speeding tom-tom patterns, and a free-rolling guitar improvisation over the looped original melody. Muthspiel's resourceful mingling of electronic and acoustic sounds and improviser's imagination allows Blade (the most melodious of drummers) to stretch out over changing backdrops, and there are two lovely ballads. A train-rhythm blues chugs over Blade's soft rumbles and admonishing snaps on Between the Beats, and Muthspiel the postbop swinger (taut and darkly McLaughlinesque behind the driving drums) hurtles through the finale of the grooving End On 4. You have to check the credits to remind yourself there are only two of them.

Vale to spend 5bn on new Amazonian mill

Vale will spend $5bn (£2.7bn) on a new steel mill complex and related operations in the Amazon state of Para, Brazil. The mill will produce 2.5m tonnes a year when it begins production in 2013 and expand to 5m tonnes, the Brazilian mining company said. Vale estimates construction costs at about $3.3bn. The company said that it will also spend $900m on a 600-megawatt plant in Barcarena to power the mill, in addition to other investments in operations and environmental and social programmes. It will be the first steel mill that Vale operates without an outside partner.
Associated Press

Morgan Stanley and JP Morgan pay $60m in fines

Morgan Stanley and JP Morgan have become the latest Wall Street financial groups to accept fines and promise to buy-back frozen bonds once sold as safe investments. The two have reached a deal with the New York attorney general, Andrew Cuomo, to pay fines totalling $60m. They will also repurchase "auction-rate securities" worth billions from investors. Last week UBS and Citigroup agreed to buy back $26bn in securities and pay fines of $250m; Merrill Lynch has offered to buy back up to $12bn. Such securities became impossible to sell when the market froze in February.
Julia Finch

Rolls-Royce plans joint venture with US firm

Rolls-Royce is planning a joint venture with Goodrich, the US aerospace systems supplier, to develop and supply engine controls. It would combine Goodrich's British engine control design and manufacturing business and Rolls-Royce's expertise in integrating control systems. The Goodrich operations employ around 1,100 in Birmingham and Belfast and the joint venture will involve up to 500 Rolls-Royce employees at Bristol, Derby, Dahlewitz in Germany and in Indianapolis in the US. Negotiations with employee representatives are expected to take place shortly.
Mark Milner

BP blames partners after Russia bans Dudley

The divisions between the warring factions at TNK-BP deepened yesterday after its chief executive, Robert Dudley, was reportedly banned from working in Russia for two years for breaching labour laws. BP said it was "very disappointed" by the decision and that Dudley would remain chief executive pending the outcome of an appeal. The company claimed the decision was a further example of what it called administrative activity orchestrated by the other shareholders, a consortium of Russian billionaires. Dudley has already left Russia but continues to run the company from abroad.

Lower margins push down npower profits

German utility RWE said operating profits from its UK energy business, npower, fell 3% in the first half of the year after adjusting for currency movements. The decline came on the back of lower margins in npower's retail arm, which supplies energy to homes and businesses across Britain. Group first-half revenues were up 13% to €24.7bn, though operating profits fell 8% to €3.9bn as energy trading failed to match last year's record results. RWE said the outlook for full-year earnings prospects was positive and it expected to at least match last year's operating performance.
Mark Milner

Lewis Altman, who has died aged 90, was the stockbroker who, in the words of a senior London Stock Exchange official, "tweaked the council's nose too often". Extremely able but abrasive, the secretive Altman was anti-establishment, with colourful clients and a penchant for transactions that outwitted bigger rivals and tested regulators. He was also prepared to challenge the then all-powerful council - obtaining an unprecedented high court injunction on one occasion to prevent disciplinary action being taken.

Altman also upset many in the exchange's hierarchy by supporting the admission of women as members. In 1973, his long-time personal and business partner Anne Hallé, who died last year, was among the first to join.

Altman became a major trader in far eastern tin and rubber shares, often buying and selling control of British-owned mines and plantations to local Chinese interests. He was an expert in guanxi - the complex network of personal relationships and favours that still dictates a lot of Chinese business.

But involvement in a major currency scandal resulted in Altman's expulsion from Stock Exchange membership after three decades, in 1978. He and his firm, Lewis Altman & Co, were convicted of breaching exchange control regulations in the biggest prosecution of its kind.

This system, introduced in 1947 and ended in 1979 by the Thatcher government, required UK-resident purchasers of foreign shares to buy investment dollars at a premium above the official exchange rate. On sale, 75% of that investment dollar premium was repaid. During the early 70s, with the dollar premium high, "premium stripping" - obtaining reimbursement of inflated or even unpaid premiums - became a costly scam for Britain's foreign exchange reserves.

In February 1977, Altman, his firm and others were charged with conspiracy and breaches of the Exchange Control Act. Circular transactions totalling £6.7m between November 1974 and May 1975 generated profits of £2m - worth £12m today - by reclaiming premiums that had never been paid. Altman's firm handled the currency deals, and the money disappeared into bank accounts in Switzerland and Liechtenstein. The mastermind behind the scheme was said in court to have been one of Altman's biggest clients, a former London solicitor, Judah Binstock. He lived on the continent and was never tried.

In April 1978, Altman was fined £54,700 and his firm £155,500. Fines of just over £1m were imposed on two companies involved in the fraud. "Altman knew that Binstock was the puppet-owner pulling the strings of the corporate marionettes," stated the Guildhall magistrates' judgment. Altman denied he had known of the fraud.

The Stock Exchange refused to accept his resignation and expelled him in September 1978. However, Altman continued to work in the City through a new company, mainly doing business in the far east, for another 10 years until tougher new regulations closed him down once again.

The Binstock connection also resulted in Altman featuring in a 1979 report by Department of Trade inspectors into the affairs of the Peachey Property Corporation and its chairman Sir Eric Miller, knighted by the Labour prime minister Harold Wilson. Miller was an Altman client: he shot himself in September 1977, months after the investigation was announced.

The inspectors highlighted a £70,000 loan by Peachey in 1972 made via Lewis Altman & Co to an offshore Binstock-controlled company. Altman told the inspectors this had been arranged between Miller and Binstock. Miller had given contradictory explanations. The inspectors accepted Binstock's version that it related to a private transaction with Miller.

Altman was born in Stepney, London, the son of a warehouseman whose family had arrived as refugees from Russian pogroms. On leaving school, he went to work in the City at a newly formed firm, Raymond & Bekhor, to which he returned after war service, before forming Lewis Altman & Co in 1954.

Altman's influential contacts in the far east started with relationships formed during three years as a Japanese prisoner of war. He had enlisted in the RAF in 1940, and was captured in Bandung, Java - where he was working in the headquarters hospital - in March 1942. Shipped to Singapore, he was imprisoned first at Changi PoW camp, and then, from May to December 1943, in Thailand at various camps on the infamous Burma railway. He was at Changi from May 1944 until it was liberated in August 1945, entertaining fellow prisoners with talks on the stock market. He kept records of deaths and sickness that were handed over to war crimes investigators.

In 1945, he married Florence Camp. They were separated, and she died in 2006. He is survived by their daughter.

The government has been accused of creating laws that have a chilling effect on freedom of expression in the UK in a sharply critical report from the United Nations' committee on human rights. The report calls for the reform of Britain's libel laws and controls introduced under recent terrorism laws.

The government's use of the Official Secrets Act to prevent issues of public interest being published is also condemned in an intervention from the UN which warns that public servants are being gagged even where national security is not at risk.

The criticisms are made as part of the committee's analysis of a report which the UK is required to submit to the UN every three years, appraising human rights in its jurisdiction.

Among the problems identified, the UN says:

· Terrorism Act 2006 provisions covering encouragement of terrorism are too broad and vague, and should be amended so that their application does not lead to "a disproportionate interference with freedom of expression".

· Libel laws should be reformed to end so-called "libel tourism", whereby wealthy foreigners have gone to the high court to sue over articles that would not warrant action in their own country.

· Powers under the Official Secrets Act have been "exercised to frustrate former employees of the crown from bringing into the public domain issues of genuine public interest, and can be exercised to prevent the media from publishing such matters".

The committee also warns that, in the age of the internet, Britain's unduly restrictive libel laws create the danger of affecting freedom of expression worldwide, contrary to a UN covenant on civil and political rights which guarantees the right to freedom of speech and to exchange ideas and information "regardless of borders".

On the phenomenon of libel tourism, the case which has provoked most concern is that of the American researcher Dr Rachel Ehrenfeld, who was sued in London by a Saudi businessman and his two sons over a book which was not published in the UK, although 23 copies had been sold here via the internet and one chapter was available online. The action led to the New York state legislature passing legislation to protect writers and publishers working there from defamation judgments elsewhere, unless the defendants enjoyed the same freedom of speech rights as under New York and US federal law.

The UK government has been urged to consider "a so-called 'public figure' exception", which would require a would-be claimant to prove actual malice by a publisher or author. This would apply in cases involving public officials and prominent public figures, as currently exists in the US, where a public figure can only sue for libel if he or she can demonstrate malice, recklessness or indifference to the truth.

The 2006 Terrorism Act's "broad and vague" definition of the offence of "encouragement of terrorism" - an offence which can attract a jail term of seven years - was also criticised by the committee.

"In particular, a person can commit the offence even when he or she did not intend members of the public to be directly or indirectly encouraged by his or her statement to commit acts of terrorism, but where his or her statement was understood by some members of the public as encouragement to commit such acts," concluded the committee.

The government's abolition earlier this year of the common-law offences of blasphemy and blasphemous libel in England and Wales was noted and welcomed, as was the adoption of the civil partnership act recognising unions between gay and lesbian couples.

The UK also came under fire for its treatment of the Chagos Islanders, whose case for return to their former homes was heard by the law lords last month. The committee urged that the islanders be allowed to return, and also be compensated.

There was also condemnation over the extension of detention without charge from 14 to 28 days under the Terrorism Act. The committee was "even more disturbed" at plans to extend this to 42 days.

On the issue of the libel laws, media law specialist Mark Stephens said yesterday that "libel lawyers in this country have remained insouciant to the deficiencies highlighted by the UN" .

The civil rights organisation, Liberty, has already expressed concern about the Terrorism Act and its potential effect on free expression. "Free speech has been a victim of the 'war on terror', with offences of 'encouragement' and 'glorification' of terrorism threatening to make careless talk a crime," said a spokesperson.

Solange Knowles's self-penned blurb makes exhausting reading. At 22, she can point to parallel careers in singing, acting, songwriting and modelling for sister Beyoncé's clothing line. But when it comes to star quality, only one family member has it, and it's not Solange.

The long-delayed follow-up to her 2003 debut Solo Star, Sol-Angel is savvy R&B with a gloss you can check your reflection in, but it falls short of what she intended: to make the record Dusty Springfield or Minnie Riperton would have made, were they around in 2008. Busy production from Mark Ronson and Pharrell isn't helped by a lack of both memorable tunes and the steely spined ardour that makes Beyoncé so compelling. It's only on a pair of slowed-down, twitchy songs at the end, Cosmic Journey and I Decided, that Solange shows she doesn't always succumb to the urge to overload everything with brassy wailing.

Filmgoers all over the world will have to contain their excitement at the prospect of seeing Angels and Demons, the prequel to The Da Vinci Code, as it will only be released in May 2009. Despite a Vatican ban on the film's makers shooting in two churches - a spokesman for the diocese explained: "We would be helping them create a work that might well be beautiful but that does not conform to our views" - the adaptation of Dan Brown's book, filmed on location in Rome, is bang on schedule. "Beautiful" or not, you can be sure that Angels and Demons will have the credit: "A Ron Howard Film". However, I defy anyone to define what "A Ron Howard Film" is, because Howard is the very antithesis of an auteur.

Ever since Francois Truffaut coined the phrase "la politique des auteurs" in Cahiers du Cinéma in 1954, critics have discussed the "auteur theory", though it only became fully recognised in America eight years later in an essay by Andrew Sarris. It is an often misused term - for example the "auteur theory" does not refer to directors like Jean Renoir, Yasujiro Ozu, Alfred Hitchcock, Carl Dreyer, Luis Buñuel, Robert Bresson or Ingmar Bergman, because there is nothing theoretical about their being auteurs. It applied mainly to directors, working as contractees of the Hollywood studios who, nevertheless, revealed a distinctive style and personal vision, for instance, Nicholas Ray and Vincente Minnelli.
In 1957, in Art, another magazine for which he was a harsh critic, the 25-year-old Truffaut wrote: "The film of tomorrow appears to me as even more personal than an individual and autobiographical novel, like a confession, or a diary. The film of tomorrow will not be directed by civil servants of the camera, but by artists for whom shooting a film constitutes a wonderful and thrilling adventure. The film of tomorrow will resemble the person who made it, and the number of spectators will be proportional to the number of friends the director has. The film of tomorrow will be an act of love." This was two years before he started to practise what he preached.

Ron Howard, one of the most successful Hollywood directors for over 20 years, is a paradigm of the non-auteur, a middle-brow, middle-of-the-road film-maker who adapts his "style" to whatever subject comes his way. Whether churning out comedies (Splash, Parenthood), kids' movies (Willow, How the Grinch Stole Christmas), dramas (Apollo 13, A Beautiful Mind) or period pieces (Far and Away, Cinderella Man), there are other directors who could have made them better. A bad film by Lars Von Trier (and you can't get much worse than Dancer in the Dark) is more interesting than a "good" film by Ron Howard.

Paradoxically, although Howard's filmography is more eclectic than most, all his films are similar, not in any auteurist sense, but because they are merely what audiences expect of a genre film, competently made commercial stuff with no individual signature. Ron Howard, who, to many people, will forever remain the lanky ineffectual teenager Richie Cunningham in television's Happy Days, once said he became a director to avoid being typecast as an actor. Certainly, he has refused to be typecast as a director.

Yet auteurism and thematic or aesthetic eclecticism are not necessarily mutually exclusive - Howard Hawks, Jean Renoir, Fritz Lang were eclectic, while Alfred Hitchcock, Orson Welles and John Ford were less so. Also there were studio hacks such as Allan Dwan, WS Van Dyke, Tay Garnett, Victor Fleming, Henry Hathaway and Michael Curtiz who made excellent films because of the backing of the streamlined major studios, with their permanent crews of production designers, directors of photography, editors and costume designers. In fact, one could say that MGM, 20th Century Fox and Warner Bros were the true auteurs of their films.

Directors like Ron Howard, Ridley and Tony Scott, Adrian Lyne, Barry Sonnenfeld, Steven Soderbergh, Joel Schumacher, Rob Cohen and Stephen Sommers would probably have been better directors under the old studio system, and might even have been considered "auteurs". Since most directors today have far more autonomy than the directors of Hollywood's golden era, the "auteur theory" died when the studio system died in the late 50s. Thank goodness auteurism is still alive and well.

A colourful below-decks account of life in the Royal Navy in the era of Lord Nelson is expected to fetch £30,000 when it goes under the hammer at an auction in the US.

The 500-page diary of George Hodge, a self-educated seaman, features sea shanties and paintings, as well as erratically-spelled tales of drownings and girls "brot onboard".

The diary records Hodge's eventful life between 1790 and 1833, travelling the world, getting into skirmishes and being chased by press gangs.

The sailor writes that he was born in "the Parish of Tinmouth in the County of Northumberland" and began his career as a cabin boy in coaling vessels between the north east and London.

His journal begins: "George Hodge his Book Consisting of Difrint ports & ships that I have sailed in since the year 1790. Aged 13 years."

In 1794 he travelled to a Russian Baltic port and on the way back was captured by the French before being sent home. After another voyage three years later, he spent months on the run from press gangs, until he was caught in 1798 and made to go to sea.

Hodge joined the 64-gun ship Lancaster and spent the next nine years serving along the west African coast, and in what were then known as Ceylon and the East Indies. In 1808 he joined the 74-gun Marlborough and until 1812 was on blockade duty around Europe. After returning to Britain in 1815 he served at Greenwich.

The diary includes lists of ships, their guns, and their crew, and 192 flag formations including signals for "An enemy is in sight", "Prepare for battle" and "Enemy retreating at full speed".

One entry from July 15 1807, reads: "On shore at Point [in Portsmouth] at 3pm returnd onboard from liberty brot a girl onboard MAK [initials of girl] at 5pm the girls orderd of the ship."

An entry for December 26 1812, reads: "Fell from the top mast Mathew Donelson and was drownded."

The journal belonged to an American, J Welles Henderson, who died last year.

The joy of online banking is that you don't have to age gently in a queue whenever you need to shift money about. In principle, anyway. In fact, trying to negotiate your way through cyberspace can take more of a toll on health, wealth and sanity than a trip down to your local branch, as Lucy O'Meara found when she tried to transfer funds online from her Nationwide account.

Her access was blocked when she answered a security question wrongly and so she called Nationwide's internet security centre, assuming that a quick identity check would readmit her. Instead she was told that the only solution was for her to re-register for internet services. She did so. Her new banking details arrived in the post a few days later but when she input them a message warned that access was barred for security reasons.

So it was back to the security team, who advised her to re-register a second time. Same result. Re-register a third time, the technical wizards told her. Same result. A 38-minute phone call to the "technical department" brought no result. "I find it laughable that Nationwide should call it a technical department as in my experience the only technical advice it provides is that one should re-register," says O'Meara, who had by now been without banking facilities for two months.

"I began to realise that I could re-register for the rest of my life without a solution."

Two days after the press office is alerted, miracles happen. Nationwide discovers that it had failed to realise that incorrect security information had prompted the saga and therefore failed to reset security questions when O'Meara re-registered.

She has now received £100 in compensation, a bouquet of flowers and an apology for the length of time it took one of Britain's biggest lenders to solve what was actually a very simple problem.

With copper climbing to a one-week high after its recent wobble, Antofagasta was the biggest riser in the FTSE 100, adding 25.5p to 563.5p. Kazakhmys climbed 57p to £12.62, while Anglo American was 132p better at £29.23.

Merrill Lynch issued a positive note on the sector, saying: "Ask yourself the question: what is the risk/reward of being underweight miners as the Olympics in China draw to a close and Chinese manufacturers restart?"

Rio Tinto rose 142p to £48 as Sanford Bernstein said the shares could be worth £80 each, while BHP Billiton bounced 70p to £15.82 after the same analysts put a £25 target on its shares. There was also talk that, following Xstrata's move on platinum specialist Lonmin, BHP might be interested in South Africa's Impala Platinum. But Evolution Securities was not convinced a move was imminent: "Currently BHP has negligible exposure to platinum and may consider Impala, the world's second-largest producer of platinum group metals," the broker said. "However, we feel that [BHP's] bid for Rio Tinto may preoccupy the company for this year."

Ferrochrome producer International Ferro Metals added 7.5p to 72.25p as Merrill set a 200p target.

With miners adding about 25 points and Wall Street more than 100 points ahead by the time London closed, the FTSE 100 ended 48.8 points higher at 5497.4. The one non-commodity company in the top ten risers in the leading index was RSA Insurance, up 5.8p to 146.7p on renewed bid speculation.

Among the fallers, Barclays lost 5p to 346.5p as house broker Cazenove downgraded from outperform to in-line, and Goldman Sachs warned of more hefty write-offs to come. Goldman said: "On Barclays' credit market exposures we believe there is the potential for up to £4.6bn of further write-downs. These are spread across the whole credit portfolio but some may take longer to crystallise as they sit within the loan book. We forecast £1.5 bn further write-downs over the next 18 months as we believe exposures could move closer to other marks in the market."

Aero-engine maker Rolls-Royce slipped 15.5p to 387.5p. A couple of recent negative notes from Morgan Stanley and Dresdner Kleinwort outweighed news of a joint venture with US group Goodrich.

Ahead of today's launch of rival trading platform Turquoise, the London Stock Exchange continued its decline. It fell another 16p to 797p despite spending £3.6m on buying back its own shares in the past two days.

Regional newspaper group Johnston Press lost 9p to 54p as Landsbanki moved its recommendation from hold to reduce ahead of the company's half-year results at the end of this month.

"The trade press has reported a soft cost-cutting exercise at Johnston in recent days and mooted various title closures," said the broker. This could presage a formal move to cut £10m of costs, it added. "Elsewhere, if strategic investor Usaha Tegas [of Malaysia] intended to add to its holding, it would have done so before now." Meanwhile US-based investment firm Harris Associates has sold about 2m shares in Johnston to take its stake to 10.82%.

Royal rat-catcher Rentokil Initial slipped 5p to 78.75p as UBS cuts its target price from 105p to 90p given last month's profit warning. The bank said: "The new management team are still confident of recovery at Rentokil but clearly the starting base looks to be lower than originally expected - with the problems inherited from the previous management being compounded by a weakening economic background."

Housebuilders were unwanted after Bellway confirmed that the market continued to be tough, with reservations down 45% in the second half of its financial year. Bellway fell 16.5p to 560p, Taylor Wimpey lost 5.75p to 48p and Barratt Developments dropped 10.75p to 124.75p.

Software specialist Autonomy jumped 62p to £10.58 after a positive note from Panmure Gordon. Analyst George O'Connor said: "Autonomy should join the top companies club, the FTSE 100, from September 10. Ahead of this we expect the company to maintain its usual heady pace of customer announcements. With the share headed for FTSE status, and the resultant index buying that will incur, we are upping our recommendation from hold to buy."

Software provider NetDimensions jumped 24% to 9.75p after well received interim results. Analysts at Landsbanki pointed out the company had a cash pile of about £3.4m, compared to its market capitalisation of just over £2m.

Afren, the oil and gas company principally working in Nigeria, added 6p to 94.5p as analysts at energy advisory firm Tristone Capital put an outperform recommendation on the business with a 200p price target. Finally, punters' favourite Desire Petroleum rose 8.5p to 83.5p on upbeat news on its Falkland Island projects.

Accra money

Vodafone, steady at 139.9p, yesterday received the green light from the Ghanaian parliament to buy majority control of the country's biggest telecoms business despite opposition from some MPs and union leaders. The national assembly voted 124-74 in favour of a deal that will see Vodafone pay £450m for a 70% stake in Ghana Telecom and the government inject its fibre-optic network into the venture. Opposition leaders had said the price tag was too low but president John Agyekum Kufuor said: "The government is confident it is doing the right thing for the interests of Ghana."
